highlights.para: The information in this chapter describes how to use windows in the GNOME desktop. This chapter describes the functions that are associated with the Sawfish window manager.

sect1.title: Windows, Workspaces, and Viewports
sect1.para: You can display many windows at the same time on your desktop. You can run different applications in each window in the following desktop areas:

listitem.para: Workspaces
Viewports

sect1.para: You can subdivide your desktop into separate workspaces. You can display only one workspace at a time, but you can have windows open in all your other workspaces. You can divide your workspaces into subdivisions that are called viewports. You can display only one viewport at a time, but you can have windows open in all of your other viewports.

The Desk Guide applet displays a visual representation of your windows, workspaces, and viewports. shows the Desk Guide applet when your desktop has four workspaces with four viewports in each workspace.

In the first workspace, the four viewports contain one window each. Windows can straddle viewports. That is, part of a window can appear in one viewport, and the other part of the window can appear in an adjacent viewport. In the second workspace in , a window straddles the first two viewports.

Each workspace and viewport has the same panels, desktop background objects, and background as all other workspaces and viewports. Your workspaces are arranged in a list. You can view the workspace list in the Root menu. By default, your workspace list contains four workspaces, with one viewport in each workspace.

You can use the Sawfish window manager capplet to specify the default number of workspaces. You can also add more workspaces at any time. When you add a workspace, the new workspace is inserted immediately next to the current workspace.

You can move your workspaces to rearrange the order of workspaces in the workspace list. The order of the workspace list affects where the workspaces are located in the Desk Guide applet. The order of the workspace list also affects the list order in the Root menu. You can also move or copy windows to other workspaces.

sect2.title: Window Manager Behavior
sect2.para: A window manager controls how windows appear and behave on your desktop. The window manager manages where your windows are located, which window has focus, and the style of the frame on the windows. The window frame contains buttons that enable you to perform standard actions such as moving, closing, and resizing windows.

You can work with many different window managers in your desktop. You can choose which window manager to use in the Window Manager capplet. You must use a GNOME-compliant window manager, such as Sawfish, for all GNOME features to function correctly.

You can configure many window management settings in the Sawfish window manager. This manual describes the functions that are associated with the default configuration of the Sawfish window manager. The default configuration is specified in the Sawfish window manager capplet. This manual also describes the default functions of the Crux frame style.

sect1.title: Types of Window
sect1.para: The desktop features the following types of windows:

listitem.para: Application windows
When you start an application, an application window opens. The window manager applies a frame to the application window.
The titlebar along the top edge of the window frame contains buttons that you can use to work with the window. The titlebar contains one button on the left side and three on the right side.
The following figure shows a typical application window.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a typical application window

listitem.para: Dialog windows
A dialog window is a popup window in which you enter information or commands. The dialog appears within a window frame.

You can use the titlebar along the top edge of the dialog window frame to work with the window. You can use the titlebar to move the dialog around the desktop. The titlebar also contains a button that enables you to do the following:
Close the dialog window
Open the Window menu

Typically you open a dialog window from an application window. When you open a dialog window, the window is usually raised and has focus. Some dialog windows do not allow you to use the application until you close the dialog. Both of these behaviors are options that you can select in the Sawfish window manager capplet.
The following figure shows a typical dialog window.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a typical dialog window

sect2.title: Window Frames
sect2.para: A window frame is a border around a window. The window frame contains a titlebar. The titlebar normally contains buttons that you can use to work with the window.

You can apply several styles of window frame to your windows. The style of a window frame determines how the frame looks and which buttons are on the frame. You can choose a default frame style for all your windows in the Sawfish window manager capplet. You can also choose a different frame style for each individual window.
The default frame style is Crux. This manual describes the functions that are associated with the Crux frame style.
Other frame styles have a different visual design to the Crux frame style. For example, shows an application window in the MicroGUI frame style.

figure.title: Application Window in MicroGUI Frame Style

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of an application window in MicroGUI frame style

sect2.para: shows a dialog window in the MicroGUI frame style.

figure.title: Dialog Window in MicroGUI Frame Style

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a dialog window in MicroGUI frame style

sect2.para: Application windows in the Crux and MicroGUI frame styles have four buttons in the titlebar. Other frame styles can have a different number of buttons in the titlebar. For example, application windows in the smaker frame style have only two buttons.

Other frame styles can assign different functions to the buttons in the titlebar. For example, in the Crux frame style, if you click on the button on the left of the titlebar the window closes. In the smaker frame style, if you click on the button on the left of the titlebar the window minimizes.
You can view tooltips for the buttons and other control elements on window frames. Tooltips appear when you point to the control element. The following shows the tooltip for the Maximize button.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of tooltip for Maximize button

sect3.title: Window Frame Control Elements
sect3.para: You can use the window frame to perform various actions with the window. In particular, the titlebar contains various active control elements. The following figure shows the titlebar of an application window in the Crux frame style.

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of an application window

sect3.para: Dialog windows also contain some of the window frame control elements. describes the active control elements on window frames in the Crux frame style, from left to right.

entry.para: The button on the left of the titlebar. Click on the button to close the window. If the window is in a window group, press Shift then click on the Close Window button to close all windows in the group.
You can also right-click on the Close Window button to open the Window menu.
You can use the titlebar to perform the following actions:

listitem.para: To give focus to the window click on the titlebar.
To move the window grab the titlebar and drag the window to the new location.
To shade the window, double-click on the titlebar. To unshade the window, double-click on the titlebar again.
To resize the window vertically middle-click and hold the titlebar, then drag up or drag down.

If the window is at the top of the stacking order , right-click on the titlebar to lower the window to the bottom. If the window is not at the top of the stacking order, right-click on the titlebar to raise the window to the top. The raise and lower operations work within layers.

entry.para: The first button in the group of three buttons on the right side of the titlebar. Click on the Minimize button to minimize the window. You can also right-click on the Minimize button to open the Window menu.
The second button in the group of three buttons on the right side of the titlebar. Use the Maximize button to perform the following actions:

listitem.para: To maximize the window click on the Maximize button. To restore the window click on the Maximize button again.
To maximize the window vertically, middle-click on the Maximize button. To restore the window click on the Maximize button again.
To maximize the window horizontally, right-click on the Maximize button. To restore the window click on the Maximize button again.

entry.para: The third button in the group of three buttons on the right side of the titlebar. Click on the button to shade the window. To unshade the window click on the button again.
The border around the window. Use the border to perform the following actions:

listitem.para: To resize the window grab the border and drag the border to the new size.
To move the window middle-click and hold the border and drag the window to the new location.

If the window is at the top of the stacking order, right-click on the border to lower the window to the bottom. If the window is not at the top of the stacking order, right-click on the border to raise the window to the top. The raise and lower operations work within layers.

sect1.title: Applets and Menus for Working With Windows, Workspaces, and Viewports

indexterm.secondary: applets and menus for working with

sect1.para: This section describes the applets and menus that you can use to work with windows, workspaces, and viewports.

sect2.title: Tasklist Applet
sect2.para: The Tasklist applet displays a button for each window that is open. The Tasklist applet enables you to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: Minimize and restore windows.
Give focus to windows.
Shade and unshade windows.
Stick and unstick windows.
Close and kill windows.

sect2.para: When you open a window, the Tasklist applet displays a button that represents the window. The tasklist buttons show which windows are open. You can view which windows are open, even if some windows are minimized, or other windows overlap a window. The Tasklist applet can display buttons for the windows in your current workspace and viewport, or in all workspaces and viewports. To select this option, you must change the properties of the Tasklist applet.
shows the Tasklist applet when the following windows are open:
The buttons in the applet show the status of your windows. explains the information that the tasklist buttons provide about the window. The examples in refer to .

table.title: Window Status Information on Tasklist Buttons

entry.para: Indicates that the window has focus.
No square brackets around window title
Indicates that the window is on the desktop and is not minimized.
Indicates that the window is minimized.
Number in parentheses before window title
Indicates that the button represents a group of windows that have the same name. The number in parentheses indicates the number of windows in the task group.

sect2.para: You can use the Tasklist applet to perform the following actions on windows:

listitem.para: If the window has focus, click on the button that represents the window to minimize the window.
If the window is minimized, click on the button that represents the window to restore the window.
If the window is not minimized and not in focus, click on the button that represents the window to give focus to the window.

sect3.title: Task Menu
sect3.para: A task menu contains menu items that enable you to perform various tasks on windows. For example, task menu items enable you to minimize and restore a window. To open a task menu, right-click on the button that represents the window with which you want to work.

The items that appear on the menu depend on the state of the window that the tasklist button represents. For example, if the window is not shaded, the popup menu contains a Shade item. If the window is shaded, the popup menu contains an Unshade item.
lists the items that you can choose from a task menu.

entry.para: To minimize the window to the Tasklist applet, choose Iconify. If the window is already minimized, choose Restore to restore the window.
To reduce the window so that only the titlebar is visible, choose Shade. If the window is already shaded, choose Unshade to display the full window.

To set the window to display in any workspace or viewport that you view, choose Stick. If the window is already set to stick, choose Unstick to set the window to display only in the current workspace or current viewport.
To close the window choose Close window.
To close all windows that are open for the application, choose Kill app.

note.para: If you choose Kill app on a dialog window, any other windows that were opened by the application are closed.

sect3.title: Task Groups
sect3.para: The Tasklist applet allows you to group tasks of the same name into a single tasklist button. You click on the button to display a list of the tasks in the task group. The following figure shows a task group list.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of a task group list

sect3.para: The task group list uses the same notation as the tasklist buttons.
You can use a task group list to perform the following actions on windows:

listitem.para: Restore the window if the window is minimized. Click on the tasklist button to display the task group list. Click on the item that represents the window to restore the window.

Give focus to the window, if the window is not minimized and not in focus. Click on the tasklist button to display the task group list. Click on the item that represents the window to give focus to the window.

sect3.para: You can also use the task menu to perform actions on windows in task groups. You can open a task menu in the following ways:

listitem.para: Click on the tasklist button to display the task group list, then right-click on an item in the task group list.

Right-click on the button that represents the task group. When you open the task menu from a task group, the menu items apply to all windows in the task group. For example, you can choose Shade All to shade all windows in the task group.

sect2.title: Desk Guide Applet
sect2.para: The Desk Guide applet displays a visual representation of your workspace list and your viewports. Your workspaces appear as buttons on the applet. Your viewports appear as subdivisions of the workspace buttons on the applet. To switch to another workspace or viewport, click on the workspace or viewport.

sect3.title: Desk Guide Applet and Workspaces
sect3.para: shows the Desk Guide applet when your desktop has four workspaces.

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of Desk Guide with workspaces

sect3.para: The button that represents the current workspace is pressed in. The current workspace in is the workspace at the left. To switch to another workspace click on the workspace.
The position of workspaces in the Desk Guide applet follows a table structure. The workspace at the top left of the following figure corresponds to the workspace at the top of the workspace list.

The workspace at the top right corresponds to the second workspace. The workspace at the bottom left corresponds to the third workspace, and so on. The Desk Guide applet places workspaces from left to right across the Desk Guide rows. When the applet reaches the end of a row, the next workspace is placed at the beginning of the next row.
To specify the table structure for the applet you change the properties for the applet. For example shows the Desk Guide applet when the table structure is two rows and two columns of workspaces.
The table structure of the Desk Guide applet determines the position of workspaces when you add, move, or copy workspaces.

sect3.title: Desk Guide Applet and Viewports
sect3.para: shows the Desk Guide applet when your desktop has four workspaces with four viewports in each workspace.

textobject.phrase: Annotated screenshot of Desk Guide with viewports

sect3.para: The current viewport is highlighted with a checked background. The current viewport in is the viewport in the top left of the current workspace. To switch to another viewport click on the viewport.

sect3.title: Desk Guide Tasklist
sect3.para: The Desk Guide tasklist lists the tasks currently running in your session. To open the Desk Guide tasklist click on the tasklist arrow button. To switch to a task click on the task in the tasklist.

sect2.title: Window Menu
sect2.para: The Window menu is a menu of commands and submenus that you can use to perform actions on your windows. To open the Window menu perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Right-click on the Close Window button on the window that you want to work with.
Press-and-hold the modifier key then middle-click on any part of the window that you want to work with. The default modifier key is the meta key.

sect2.para: describes the commands and submenus in the Window menu.

The submenu contains the following items:

Cyclable: Deselect this option if you do not want the window to appear when you cycle through your windows.
In window list: Deselect this option if you do not want the window to appear in the Root menu or on the Desk Guide display.
In GNOME task list: Deselect this option if you do not want the window to appear in either the Tasklist applet or the Desk Guide applet.

To add the window to another window group choose the other window group from the submenu.
To remove the window from the window group choose New group.
Opens a submenu that contains items that you can use to send the window to another workspace.
The submenu contains the following items:

listitem.para: Previous workspace: Choose this item to send the window to the workspace before the current workspace.
Next workspace: Choose this item to send the window to the workspace after the current workspace.
Copy to previous: Choose this item to create a copy of the window in the workspace before the current workspace, and switch to that workspace.
Copy to next: Choose this item to create a copy of the window in the workspace after the current workspace, and switch to that workspace.

The submenu contains the following items:

listitem.para: Raise: Choose this item to move the window to the top of the stacking order within the layer.
Lower: Choose this item to move the window to the bottom of the stacking order within the layer.
Upper layer: Choose this item to increment the layer that the window is in by one.
Lower layer: Choose this item to decrement the layer that the window is in by one.

The submenu contains the following items:

listitem.para: Normal: Choose this item if you want the window to have an application window titlebar and borders.
Title-only: Choose this item if you want the window to have an application window titlebar and no borders.
Border-only: Choose this item if you want the window to have a dialog window titlebar and borders.
Top-border: Choose this item if you want the window to have a dialog window titlebar and no borders.
None: Choose this item if you want the window to have no titlebar and no borders.

Opens a submenu that contains items that you can use to save the current settings of the window. The next time that you open the application, the window uses these settings. The items in the History submenu are useful if, for example, you want an application window to open as follows:
The window is in a specified location.
The window is a specified size.
The window has particular attributes selected.
The submenu contains the following items:

listitem.para: Remember position: Choose this item to save the location of the window on the desktop.
Remember dimensions: Choose this item to save the dimensions of the window.
Remember attributes: Choose this item to save the attributes that are set in the Toggle, Frame type, and Frame style submenus.
Forget saved state: Choose this item to discard all saved settings. The settings of the window are reset to the default location, dimensions, and attributes.

sect2.title: Root Menu
sect2.para: You can use the Root menu to navigate between windows and workspaces. To open the Root menu middle-click on the desktop background. The following figure shows the Root menu.
describes the items that the Root menu contains.

sect3.title: Using the Root Menu to Work With Windows
sect3.para: From the Root menu, you can view a list of all windows that are currently open. You can also choose a window to give focus to. To view the window list, middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu, then choose Windows. shows an example of the window list that is displayed from the Root menu:
The window list enables you to give focus to windows that are open in all workspaces and viewports.

A radio button that is selected indicates which window has focus. For example, in gedit has focus. If an application has more than one window open, the application name appears as a submenu in the window list. For example, in the Netscape application is a submenu from which you can choose one of the Netscape application windows. That is, you can choose to give focus to the browser, Composer, or Mail & Newsgroup windows.
The window list also uses a system of notation to indicate the status of windows. describes this notation. The examples in refer to .

sect3.title: Using the Root Menu to Work With Workspaces
sect3.para: The workspace list enables you to do the following:

listitem.para: View the list of workspaces.
Switch between workspaces.
Perform other workspace-related tasks, such as inserting workspaces.

sect3.para: The following figure shows the default workspace list.

Choose this item to copy the windows from the current workspace to the next workspace. If the number of workspaces on your desktop is greater than the minimum number of workspaces, the current workspace is deleted.

Choose this item to swap the position of the current workspace with the position of the next workspace.
Choose this item to swap the position of the current workspace with the position of the previous workspace.

sect2.title: Using the Menu Panel to Work With Windows
sect2.para: From the Menu Panel, you can view a list of all windows that are currently open. You can also choose a window to give focus to. To view the window list, click on the icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel. The following figure shows an example of the window list that is displayed from the Menu Panel:

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of Menu Panel window list

sect2.para: The icon that you click on to display the window list changes when you change focus. The icon represents the window that currently has focus. To give focus to a window, choose that window from the window list.
The window list lists the windows in all workspaces. The windows in all workspaces other than the current workspace, are listed below a separator line.
You cannot move the icon that you click on to display the window list.
You can also use the Root menu to display a window list, and give focus to windows.

sect1.title: Manipulating Windows
sect1.para: This section describes how to manipulate windows.

sect2.title: To Give Focus to a Window
sect2.para: A window that has focus can receive input from the mouse and the keyboard. Only one window can have focus at a time. The window that has focus has a different appearance than other windows.
You can give focus to a window in any of the following ways:

listitem.para: Use the mouse
Click on the window to which you want to give focus, if the window is visible.
Use a shortcut key

You can use a shortcut key to switch between the windows that are open in the current workspace or viewport. The default shortcut key to switch between windows is ModifierTab. To give focus to a window, release the keys.
Use the window list from the Menu Panel
Click on the icon at the extreme right of the Menu Panel to open a window list. Choose the window that you want to give focus to from the menu.
Use the window list from the Root menu
Middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu, then choose Windows. A list of your windows is displayed. Choose the window that you want to give focus to from the list.
Use the Tasklist applet
Double-click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet.
Use the Desk Guide applet
Open the Desk Guide tasklist, then choose the window that you want to give focus to from the Desk Guide tasklist.

sect2.title: To Minimize a Window
sect2.para: To minimize a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Click on the Minimize button on the window frame.
Open the Window menu, then choose Minimize.
If the window has focus, click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet. If the window does not have focus, double-click on the button that represents the window.
Right-click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet. Choose Iconify.

sect2.title: To Maximize a Window
sect2.para: When you maximize a window, the window expands as much as possible. If the maximize mode of a panel specifies that windows can cover the panel, the maximized window can cover the panel.
To maximize a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: To maximize the window vertically and horizontally, click on the Maximize button on the window frame.
To maximize the window vertically only, middle-click on the Maximize button on the window frame.
To maximize the window horizontally only, right-click on the Maximize button on the window frame.
To maximize the window vertically and horizontally, open the Window menu. Choose Maximize.

sect2.title: To Restore a Window
sect2.para: To restore a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: If the window is maximized, click on the Maximize button on the window frame.
If the window is maximized, open the Window menu. Choose Unmaximize.
If the window is minimized, click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet.

If the window is minimized, right-click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet. Choose
Restore.

sect2.title: To Close a Window
sect2.para: To close a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Click on the Close Window button on the window frame.
Open the Window menu. Choose Close.
In the Tasklist applet, right-click on the button that represents the window. A popup menu opens. Choose Close Window.

sect2.para: If you have unsaved data in the window, you are prompted to save your data.

sect2.title: To Kill a Window
sect2.para: To send a kill signal to a window, right-click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet. A popup menu opens. Choose Kill app.

note.para: If you choose Kill app on a dialog window, any other windows opened by the application close also.

sect2.title: To Resize a Window
sect2.para: To resize a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: To resize a window vertically and horizontally point to a corner of the window. The mouse pointer changes to indicate that you can resize the window. Grab the corner and drag the window to the new size.

To resize a window horizontally point to one of the horizontal borders of the window. The mouse pointer changes to indicate that you can resize the window. Grab the corner and drag the window to the new size.

To resize a window vertically perform one of the following actions:
Point to one of the vertical borders of the window. The mouse pointer changes to indicate that you can resize the window. Grab the corner and drag the window to the new size.
Middle-click and hold on the titlebar, then drag the window to the new size.

note.para: You cannot resize some dialog windows. Also, some application windows have a minimum size below which you cannot reduce the window.

sect2.title: To Move a Window
sect2.para: To move a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Grab the titlebar of the window and drag the window to the new location.
Point to a corner or an edge of the window. The mouse pointer changes to indicate that you can resize the window. Middle-click and hold to grab the window, move the window to the new location.
Press-and-hold the modifier key then grab any part of the window that you want to move. Drag the window to the new location. The default modifier key is the meta key.

sect2.title: To Shade a Window
sect2.para: You can shade and unshade windows as follows:

entry.para: Reduce the window so that only the titlebar is visible.
Switch a window from a shaded state so that the full window is displayed.

sect2.para: To shade a window perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Click on the Shade button. To unshade the window, click on the Shade button again.
Double-click on the titlebar of the window. To unshade the window, double-click on the titlebar again.

Open the Window menu. Choose
Toggle Shaded . To unshade the window, choose
Toggle Shaded again.

Right-click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet. A popup menu opens. Choose Shade . To unshade the window, right-click on the button that represents the window, then choose Unshade .

sect2.title: To Change the Layer of a Window
sect2.para: Your desktop is structured as a sequence of layers. Each user interface item, such as a window or a panel, is a member of a layer. Each layer has a layer number. A layer number is an integer that represents the position of a layer in the stacking order. Items with a higher layer number always appear above items with a lower layer number. For example, a panel in layer four always appears above a window in layer zero.
The stacking order is the order in which windows are stacked on top of one another on your screen. The position of a window in the stacking order depends on the following:

listitem.para: The layer of which the window is a member.
The position of the window in the order of windows within the layer.

sect2.para: The window manager controls the sequence of windows on the desktop. When you open a window, the window manager assigns the window to a layer. The window manager usually assigns new windows to layer four.

The raise and lower operations work within layers. You can raise windows to the top of the stacking order within a layer. You can lower windows to the bottom of the stacking order within a layer. You can not raise a window above a window in a higher layer. Similarly, you can not lower a window below a window in a lower layer.

Panels and desktop background objects are also members of layers. You can change the layer or level that a panel resides in. In this way, you can specify whether you want the panel to be above or below windows.
Use the Desk Guide tasklist to view which layer your windows, panels, and desktop icons are in.
To change the layer that a window is in perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Open the Window menu.

To increment the layer that the window is in by one, choose
Stacking Upper layer .

To decrement the layer that the window is in by one, choose
Stacking Lower layer .

note.para: The desktop is in layer zero. If you decrease the layer that a window is in to below zero, the window is no longer visible on the desktop. However, a button that represents the window appears on the Tasklist and Desk Guide applets. You can use the Tasklist applet to close the window.

sect2.title: To Raise and Lower a Window
sect2.para: The raise and lower operations work within layers. You can raise windows to the top of the stacking order within a layer. You can lower windows to the bottom of the stacking order within a layer. You can not raise a window above a window in a higher layer. Similarly, you can not lower a window below a window in a lower layer.
To raise a window to the top of the stacking order perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Right-click on the titlebar or the border of the window.

Open the Window menu, then choose
Stacking Raise .

sect2.para: To lower a window to the bottom of the stacking order perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: If the window is at the top of the stacking order, right-click on the titlebar or the border of the window.

Open the Window menu, then choose
Stacking Lower .

sect2.para: If you want your windows to rise when they receive focus, configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Raise windows when they are focused

sect2.title: To Ignore a Window
sect2.para: You can configure a window so that the window manager ignores the window. When the window manager ignores a window, the window does not have a frame.

To configure a window so that the window manager ignores the window, open the Window menu. Choose
Toggle Ignored .

To reconfigure a window so that the window manager does not ignore the window, open the Window menu. To open the Window menu, press-and-hold the modifier key then middle-click on any part of the window. The default modifier key is the meta key.

sect2.title: To Set a Window to Stick
sect2.para: When a window is set to stick, the window appears in any workspace or viewport that you view.
To set a window to stick, perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para:
Open the Window menu. Choose
Toggle Sticky . To set the window to appear only in the current workspace or viewport, choose
Toggle Sticky again.

Right-click on the button that represents the window in the Tasklist applet, then choose Stick. To set the window to appear only in the current workspace or viewport, right-click on the button that represents the window, then choose Unstick .

sect2.title: To Group Windows
sect2.para: You can group windows so that you can minimize and restore several windows at one time. You can use window groups to group windows in different applications. You work with window groups from any Window menu. To display a list of your window groups, open a Window menu then choose In group.

When you open a window on the desktop, a window group is created for the window. The window is the sole member of this window group. You can add the window to another group. You can also remove a window from a group.
You can use the Sawfish window manager capplet to create a persistent window group. A persistent window group remains in your window group list even after you end and restart a session.

sect3.title: To Create a Persistent Window Group
sect3.para: A persistent window group remains in your window group list even after you end and restart a session. You can create a persistent window group, and then assign windows to be part of the group. You can also configure your desktop to apply certain actions that you perform on one window to all windows in the group.
To create a persistent window group perform the following steps:

listitem.para:
To start the Control Center open the Global Menu, then choose
Programs Settings Sawfish window manager Miscellaneous . You use the Persistent group ids list box to create persistent window groups.
To create a persistent window group, click on the Add button to display the Add dialog. Use the Add drop-down combination box to specify a name for the group. Click OK.
To edit the name of a persistent window group, click on the Edit button to display the Edit dialog. Use the Edit drop-down combination box to specify a name for the group. Click OK.

To delete a persistent window group, select the group in the Persistent group ids list box. Click on the
Delete option to delete the selected group.
Click OK to save your changes.

sect3.title: To Add a Window to a Window Group
sect3.para: To add a window to another window group open the Window menu for the window. Choose In group. A list of all the available window groups is displayed. Choose the window group to which you want to add the window.

note.para: A window can only be in one window group at a time.

sect3.title: To Remove a Window From a Window Group
sect3.para:
To remove a window from a window group open the Window menu for the window. Choose
In group New group . A new window group is created for the window. The window is the sole member of this window group. The new window group has the same name as the window that you remove from the window group.

sect3.title: To Minimize a Window Group
sect3.para: You can configure your desktop so that when you minimize one window in a window group, all windows are minimized. Configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Iconifying a window also iconifies the

sect3.para: To minimize all windows in the window group, minimize one of the windows.

sect3.title: To Restore a Minimized Window Group
sect3.para: You can configure your desktop so that when you restore one window in a window group, all windows are restored. Configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Uniconifying a window also uniconifies the

sect3.para: To restore all windows in the window group, restore one of the windows.

sect3.title: To Close a Window Group
sect3.para: To close all windows in a window group press Shift then click on the Close Window button on the window frame.

sect2.title: Creating a Matched Window
sect2.para: You can configure a window to have particular characteristics when you open the window. For example, you can configure a window to open maximized, in a particular workspace, with a particular frame style. To configure a window that opens with particular characteristics, you must create a matched window.

To create a matched window, you use the Matched Windows dialog in the Sawfish window manager capplet. In the dialog, you specify the name of the window to match, and characteristics to assign to that window. When a window opens, Sawfish checks whether the window corresponds to a matched window in the Matched Windows dialog. If the window does correspond to a matched window, the window opens with the characteristics assigned to the matched window.

You can also create a matched window to match properties of the window other than the name. For example, you can create a matched window to match the class of the window or the name of the window icon.
You can assign many characteristics to the matched window. You can assign characteristics such as placement behavior, focus behavior, frame style, and other miscellaneous characteristics.

sect2.title: To Move a Window to Another Workspace
sect2.para: You can move a window to another workspace in either of the following ways:

listitem.para: Use the Window menu

Open the Window menu. To move the window to the next workspace choose
Send window to Next workspace . To move the window to the previous workspace choose
Send window to Previous workspace .
Drag the window to another workspace

You can drag a window to another workspace if you configure the edge flip feature appropriately. The edge flip feature enables you to select another workspace when you point to the edge of the screen. To use the edge flip feature you must configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Select the next desktop when the pointer hits the screen edge
Hitting the screen edge selects the next

sect2.para: The configuration of your desktop can mean that when you move a window to another workspace, a workspace is added.

sect2.title: To Copy a Window to Another Workspace
sect2.para: You can use the Window menu to copy a window to another workspace. When you copy a window to another workspace, the window appears in the workspace when you switch to the workspace. The window sticks to the workspace that you copy the window to, and the workspace that you copy the window from.

To copy a window to the next workspace, open the Window menu, then choose
Send window to Copy to next .

To copy a window to the previous workspace, open the Window menu, then choose
Send window to Copy to previous .

To remove all copies of a window except one, open the Window menu from the window that you want to retain. Choose
Toggle Sticky , then choose
Toggle Sticky again.
The configuration of your desktop can mean that when you copy a window to another workspace, a workspace is added. For more information, see .

note.para: When you copy a window to another workspace, only the window in the current workspace is represented in the Desk Guide applet.

sect2.title: To Move a Window Between Viewports
sect2.para: You can move a window between viewports in the same workspace. You can move a window between viewports in the following ways:

listitem.para: Drag the window to the viewport

Drag the window to the edge of the screen next to the viewport to which you want to move the window. Drag the window past the edge of the screen so that the window straddles the current viewport and the next viewport. Click on the viewport to which you want to move the window. Drag the window the rest of the way into the viewport.
Use the edge flip feature

You can drag a window to another viewport if you configure the edge flip feature appropriately. The edge flip feature enables you to select another viewport when you point to the edge of the screen. To use this edge flip feature you must configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Select the next desktop when the pointer hits the screen edge
Hitting the screen edge selects the next

listitem.para: Drag the window in the Desk Guide applet:
Find the button that represents the window that you want to move in the Desk Guide applet. Middle-click and hold on the button and drag the button to the new location.

sect1.title: Manipulating Workspaces and Viewports
sect1.para: This section describes how to manipulate workspaces and viewports.

sect2.title: To Switch Between Workspaces
sect2.para: You can switch between workspaces in any of the following ways:

listitem.para: Use the Desk Guide applet: Click on the workspace that you want to switch to in the Desk Guide applet.

Use the Root menu: Middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu, then choose Workspaces. This action opens a list of your workspaces and workspace-related menu items. Choose the workspace that you want to switch to from the list.

Use a shortcut key: The default shortcut keys to switch between the workspaces are:
ModifierRight arrow key: Select the next workspace.
ModifierLeft arrow key: Select the previous workspace.
The default modifier key is the meta key.

note.para: The configuration of your desktop can mean that when you use a shortcut key to select a workspace, another workspace is added. For more information, see .

listitem.para: Use the edge flip feature: Move the mouse pointer to the edge of the screen. To use this edge flip feature you must configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Select the next desktop when the pointer hits the screen edge
Hitting the screen edge selects the next
Only flip when interactively moving a window

sect2.title: To Add Workspaces
sect2.para: You can add workspaces to your desktop in the following ways:

listitem.para: Use the Root menu: For more information see .
Specify a minimum number of workspaces for your desktop: For more information see .
Configure your desktop to add workspaces automatically when you perform particular actions: For more information see .

sect3.title: To Add a Workspace Using the Root Menu
sect3.para:
To add a workspace to your workspace list middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu. Choose
Workspaces Insert workspace . The new workspace is inserted to the right of the current workspace.

sect3.title: To Specify a Minimum Number of Workspaces
sect3.para: You can use the Sawfish window manager capplet to specify the minimum number of workspaces that appear on your desktop when you start a session. To specify a minimum number of workspaces, configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager as follows:

If the number of workspaces you specify is greater than the current number of workspaces, the extra workspaces are added to the desktop. If the number of workspaces you specify is less than the current number of workspaces, the extra workspaces remain on the desktop.

sect3.title: To Add Workspaces Automatically
sect3.para: You can configure the Sawfish window manager capplet to add a workspace automatically in particular situations. A workspace can be added automatically when the current workspace is first or last in your workspace list, and you perform particular actions.
A workspace is added if you perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para:
If the workspace is first, and you perform one of the following actions:
Move the workspace to the left.
Send or copy a window to the previous workspace with the Window menu.

If the workspace is last, and you perform one of the following actions:
Move the workspace to the right.
Send or copy a window to the next workspace with the Window menu.

sect3.para: To add workspaces when you select or move workspaces, configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: When passing the first or last workspace

sect3.para: In this configuration, a workspace is added if you perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: If the workspace is first, and you select the previous workspace or move the workspace to the left.
If the workspace is last, and you select the next workspace or move the workspace to the right.

sect3.para: To add a workspace when you point to the edge of the screen, configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: When passing the first or last workspace
Select the next desktop when the pointer hits screen edge
Hitting the screen edge selects the next

sect3.para:
In this configuration, a workspace is added if you perform one of the following actions:
If the workspace is first, and you point to the left edge of the screen.
If the workspace is last, and you point to the right edge of the screen.

sect2.title: To Name Workspaces
sect2.para: The default names of your workspaces are space 1, space 2, space 3, and so on. You can assign names to your workspaces in the Sawfish window manager capplet.

sect2.title: To Merge Workspaces
sect2.para: When you merge a workspace the windows in the workspace are moved to another workspace, and the empty workspace is deleted.

To merge a workspace, middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu. Choose Workspaces, then perform one of the following actions:
To merge the workspace with the next workspace choose Merge with next. The empty workspace is deleted.
To merge the workspace with the previous workspace choose Merge with previous. The empty workspace is deleted.

note.para: The number of workspaces on your desktop is never less than the minimum number of workspaces that is specified in the Sawfish window manager capplet. If you merge workspaces, the empty workspace might not be deleted because your desktop must always have the minimum number of workspaces.

sect2.title: To Move a Workspace
sect2.para: To move a workspace middle-click on the desktop background to open the Root menu. Choose Workspaces, then perform one of the following actions:

listitem.para: To move the workspace to the right of the current workspace choose Move workspace right. The workspace swaps position with the next workspace.
To move the workspace to the left of the current workspace choose Move workspace left. The workspace swaps position with the previous workspace.

sect2.para: When you move a workspace, all the windows in the workspace are moved. The name of the workspace does not move. For example, if you move space 1 to the right, the windows move to the next workspace. The workspace takes the name of the next workspace, space 2. In summary, when you move space 1 to the right, all the windows in space 1 move to space 2.
The configuration of your desktop can mean that when you move a workspace, another workspace is added.

sect2.title: To Switch Between Viewports
sect2.para: You can switch between viewports in either of the following ways:

listitem.para: Click on the viewport in the Desk Guide applet.
Move the mouse pointer to the edge of the screen. To use this edge flip feature you must configure your desktop in the Sawfish window manager capplet as follows:

para.guilabel: Select the next desktop when the pointer hits the screen edge
Hitting the screen edge selects the next
Only flip when interactively moving a window

sect2.title: To Add Viewports
sect2.para: To add viewports to your workspaces follow these steps:

listitem.para:
To start the Control Center open the
Global Menu, then choose
Programs Settings Sawfish window manager Workspaces .

On the Workspaces tabbed section, use the Columns and Rows spin boxes to specify the following:
The number of viewports in each workspace.
The structure of the viewports in each workspace in the Desk Guide applet.

For example, if you want four viewports in your workspaces, and you want the Desk Guide to display the viewports as two columns and two rows. To specify this configuration, enter 2 in both the Columns and Rows spin boxes.
Click OK to save your changes.

note.para: If you do not want any viewports, specify 1 in both the Columns and Rows spin boxes.
